docs.lead_paragraph: The story of one writer’s path from idea to network series candidate.

headline.seo: One Writer’s Diary for Television Pitch Season

docs.abstract: Author and journalist Lisa Takeuchi Cullen presents personal diary of her experiences writing pilots during 2014 network TV pitch season; notes writers vie to become one of the select few whose ideas are accepted for production; describes arduous, high-pressure, but ultimately successful process.
docs.snippet: The story of one writer’s path from idea to network series candidate.

docs.lead_paragraph: In this economy, losers will be the biggest winners.
docs.abstract: Adam Davidson article highlights company Weird Stuff, which has thrived by acquiring goods from technology start-ups that fail; says company is a reminder that innovation, by necessity, is inextricably linked with failure.
docs.snippet: In this economy, losers will be the biggest winners.

docs.lead_paragraph: Washington's health care exchange shut down after the first few hours of open enrollment Saturday as state officials and software engineers tried to resolve a problem with tax credit calculations.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the federal government and states launch a second round of enrollment under the health care law, consumers should be aware of what's covered and what's not when buying health coverage through insurance marketplaces. Plans cover essential health benefits, pre-existing conditions and preventive care, but dental and vision benefits vary.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama's plan to extend private health coverage to the uninsured entered a new uncertain phase on Saturday as U.S. government-backed online insurance marketplaces opened their 2015 plans to millions of potential enrollees.

docs.lead_paragraph: The second sign-up season under President Barack Obama's health overhaul opened, with hopes that this time consumers will have a positive experience. Obama says about a half-million people logged into the federal government's website on Saturday, the first day of open enrollment.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jonathan Gruber, an M.I.T. professor, appears in a video saying the American people were fooled about how the health care law works.

headline.main: Affordable Care Act Supporter Ignites Fury With a Word: ‘Stupid’
headline.print_headline: Care Act Supporter Ignites Fury With a Word: ‘Stupid’

docs.abstract: Series of videos emerge that show Massachusetts Institute of Technology Prof Jonathan Gruber calling American public 'stupid' and suggesting that health care reform law passed by fooling Americans about how it works; remarks by Gruber, who acted as consultant for law, have reignited furious Republican assault on the law.
docs.snippet: Jonathan Gruber, an M.I.T. professor, appears in a video saying the American people were fooled about how the health care law works.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Many Americans with health insurance bought under the Affordable Care Act could face substantial price increases next year — in some cases as much as 20 percent.

headline.main: Cost of Coverage Under Affordable Care Act to Increase in 2015
headline.print_headline: Cost of Coverage Under Care Act Set to Increase

docs.abstract: Obama administration unveils data showing that many Americans with health insurance bought under Affordable Care Act could face substantial prices increases in 2015 unless they switch plans; notes that health plan prices vary greatly from state to state and urges consumers to shop around for best deal; Republicans argue that data offers evidence that Affordable Care Act is not working.
docs.snippet: Many Americans with health insurance bought under the Affordable Care Act could face substantial price increases next year — in some cases as much as 20 percent.
